patrol_area.description: Generates a sequence of button presses to patrol back and forth along a specified axis with a stride length. (v2)

stride.description: Number of steps in one direction before turning back.

start_positive.description: If true, starts with Right (horizontal) or Down (vertical). If false, starts with Left/Up.

patrol_area.python_script:
# Patrol Area Tool v2
axis = input_data.get('axis', 'horizontal')
stride = input_data.get('stride', 4)
cycles = input_data.get('cycles', 3)
start_positive = input_data.get('start_positive', True)

buttons = []
if axis == 'horizontal':
    dir_pos = "Right"
    dir_neg = "Left"
else:
    dir_pos = "Down"
    dir_neg = "Up"

first = dir_pos if start_positive else dir_neg
second = dir_neg if start_positive else dir_pos

for _ in range(cycles):
    for _ in range(stride):
        buttons.append(first)
    for _ in range(stride):
        buttons.append(second)

print(f'{buttons}'.replace("'", '"'))

history.commit_message: Added stride and cycle parameters to allow for wider patrol loops instead of just oscillating between two tiles.
Minor update to description and code comment to attempt to trigger sandbox environment reset.

wiggle_patrol.description: Generates a sequence of button presses to patrol back and forth along a specified axis with a stride length.

stride.description: Number of steps in one direction before turning back.

start_positive.description: If true, starts with Right (horizontal) or Down (vertical). If false, starts with Left/Up.

autopress_buttons.description: If true, the generated buttons will be pressed automatically. Safety limit of 50 buttons per turn.

wiggle_patrol.python_script:
import json

# Determine buttons based on axis
if axis.lower() == "horizontal":
    pos_btn = "Right"
    neg_btn = "Left"
else: # vertical
    pos_btn = "Down"
    neg_btn = "Up"

# Determine sequence order
if start_positive:
    first_btn = pos_btn
    second_btn = neg_btn
else:
    first_btn = neg_btn
    second_btn = pos_btn

buttons = []
for _ in range(cycles):
    # Move out
    buttons.extend([first_btn] * stride)
    # Move back
    buttons.extend([second_btn] * stride)

# Output JSON array of buttons
print(json.dumps(buttons))

enter_ecruteak_from_route37.description: Navigates from anywhere on Route 37 to the Ecruteak City gate and enters. Stops after entering.
enter_ecruteak_from_route37.python_script:
import json

current_x = int(input_data['current_x'])
current_y = int(input_data['current_y'])

buttons = []

# 1. Navigate to the gate column (x=8)
if current_x < 8:
    buttons.extend(["Right"] * (8 - current_x))
elif current_x > 8:
    buttons.extend(["Left"] * (current_x - 8))

# 2. Navigate to the gate row (y=0)
if current_y > 0:
    buttons.extend(["Up"] * current_y)

# 3. Enter Ecruteak
buttons.append("Up")

print(json.dumps(buttons))

history.commit_message: Refined tool to only handle the approach and entry to Ecruteak from Route 37, avoiding the map transition interrupt issue.

exit_ecruteak_to_route37.description: Exits Ecruteak City (South) and walks down into the Route 37 grass. Assumes player is at Ecruteak entrance (18, 35).
exit_ecruteak_to_route37.python_script:
import json

# 1. Exit Ecruteak (Down)
# 2. Walk into grass (Down, Down)
# Note: The first Down triggers the warp. The subsequent Downs happen on Route 37.
buttons = ["Down", "sleep 2000", "Down", "Down"]

print(json.dumps(buttons))

history.commit_message: New tool to handle the return trip from Ecruteak City entrance back to the hunting grounds on Route 37.
